Even with pitchers routinely underperforming at the plate compared with their teammates, the difference in scoring between the National and American League games is barely measurable.
And insisting that young fans really want to watch superannuated sluggers get workfare designated-hitter contracts at the end of their careers seems an unproven assertion at best.
Designated hitters, far from being teammates in the full sense, are merely players who don’t play defense—something that should rightly be held an insult in any sporting context.
There’s no escaping humility in the batter’s box; Mike Trout might have a $350 million contract, but he is still going to make an out more often than he reaches base safely.
But Commissioner Rob Manfred has already announced that the league has extracted a long-sought concession from the players: He has universalized the designated-hitter rule.
It will throw things into reverse, creating universally protected classes of pitchers and specialist batters who don’t play the whole game, only the parts they’re best at.
On the sandlot, in the big leagues or in metaphorical fields of dreams, baseball’s status as the national pastime is rooted in its patrimony: real, borrowed and invented.
This sense of tradition is what makes it more than a game to so many—and why the way the game is played matters as much as or more than who scores the most runs.
Excusing pitchers from batting in the National League might seem like nothing big—the designated hitter has been a feature of the American League for decades.
But it’s a third strike at the heart of the game, and it will saw off part of what has made baseball a school of character for generations of American kids.

It isn’t clear when the nearly three-month old labor dispute between Major League Baseball’s players and owners will end—or if it will.
League executives love to rationalize their brand of cultural vandalism by talking about generating more offense and courting younger fans.

But it doesn’t translate well to highlights circulated on Instagram or TikTok, and most people wouldn’t know how to wager on it.

By excusing pitchers from the batting order, the game will lose more than that example of humility.
For kids and pros alike, learning the craft of baseball is about learning to fail with dignity.
But that’s the thing about losing your soul: It happens only when you forget why you need it.
And that’s the lesson of baseball: You take your turn, and you keep trying, for the team.

But the move to universalize the designated hitter is nonsense by any standard.
Pitchers fail at the plate more often than most, but they have to keep trying.
Those of us who mourn what’s been lost will be dismissed as cranks.
For many who love the game, it’s also the end of history.
It’s the end of an era for professional baseball.
And this is even more the case for pitchers.
